##What about the layoffs?

Micro-signal, Rancaijing

A feature presentation, a daily in depth report, redefines the innovation economy.

The war and epidemic plan for Innovative Economy, a special column launched by Finance and Economics during the new type of pneumonia epidemic, focuses on the new difficulties encountered by enterprises of Innovative Economy and discusses the new countermeasures that should be adopted, hope to help small and medium-sized enterprises together to overcome challenges and seize opportunities.

By Dawn

Editor | Aalen

In the wake of the epidemic, Sleeper Cell, small and medium sized businesses are putting layoffs on the agenda. But a bad lay-off can hasten a company's demise.

Let's start with a little story. In early November, online sales in the e-cigarette industry were halted, and one E-CIGARETTE company lost half its orders in an instant. The CEO decided to lay off the staff, but hesitantly, for three months, until the end of January. At this time the outbreak, the CEO found that the account funds have not been enough for three months. He would like to carry out retirement-style layoffs, only to retain the core backbone, but found that the people have already lax, the company only "old and infirm" , the backbone is difficult to find, business is difficult to do, from bankruptcy has been not far.

For many companies, the epidemic is the last Straw.

Lay-offs are a way for companies to save themselves in times of crisis, even if they are under enormous external pressure. Many ceos are counting on layoffs to cut costs and save for Rising in the East. But lay-offs often affect the whole body, it is a complex mathematical problem, a little careless will be likely to lose.

Is Job cuts the best solution for struggling small and medium-sized enterprises in an epidemic? What should be done about the layoff bill?

"Six months is the death line, 12 months is the safety line. "

Xu Is a serial entrepreneur who saved 12 months of cash flow for his company before the outbreak. Although the company was not profitable, it avoided a shortage of funds during the outbreak.

"layoffs are essentially a matter of arithmetic, " said Xu, who has experienced mass layoffs. "You have to calculate whether or not to cut, how much to cut. ". In his last venture, he cut his team of 300 to just 60 because of a capital freeze.

"If you have $10 million left in your account, you can't spend more than $830,000 a month on a 12-month survival basis. With a monthly budget of 830,000 yuan, how many people can you support?"Xu said as he calculated.

In his experience, for a company, cash flow is a dead end in six months, a safety line in 12 months, the founder to consider whether to lay off employees, the key depends on the amount of cash on the account.

"Six months is the death line" is the industry practice. Founder Zhang Jixue said he would only live six to seven months if his company's revenues were to fall to zero when new wave media announced 500 job cuts on February 10. Although the company has $1 billion in cash on its books, it has a life span of only six months.

"If the cash reserves are less than six months, then you have to start thinking about layoffs, because if you don't, the company may not survive, " Xu said.

But in the specific implementation, in addition to targeting the six-month death line, the founder also has to consider the cost of layoffs and business replacement costs. In other words, the comparison is to see if the replacement cost of the business is lower than the cost of layoffs.

Image / visual China

"I run a restaurant, for example, and I lose $200,000 a month because I can't open the door because of the epidemic. If I judge that the epidemic won't end in the next five months, and my store won't open, that means I'll lose a million dollars in the next five months. If I open a new restaurant and it can be done within one million yuan, then I won't hesitate to lay off the staff and close the shop immediately." "there is money to be made by closing the shop, and I will reopen it when the epidemic is over. "

This is similar to the stock idea: When the stock price continued to fall, is the choice to stop losses in time to buy at the bottom, or all the way hard fight until the position was closed. The core of this lies in the judgment of the external environment and the future of the company, which is where the greatest uncertainty lies.

In 2015, at the height of China's Internet O2o Boom, Xu joined the battle over shared travel. After several rounds of funding, the company quickly expanded to 300 employees. At this time, a shares broke out of the stock market, the first-class market quickly into the capital winter, known for burning money in the field of O2o investment was blocked by VC circle.

With only six months of cash left in the company, the investors called a board meeting to recommend that Xu lay off workers, but Xu strongly refused. His reasoning: "The company's business data is still rising, and the investors in the new round of financing still seem to be interested. " Xu judged that the company could survive the crisis in six months, but investors did not think so. Xu turned out to be wrong, and three months later he had to go through a round of clean-up layoffs.

"investors generally encourage you to lay off people because their money is already in, and they certainly don't want the company to go bankrupt right away. Their logic is: As long as the company has money on its books, there's still a chance to turn it around. If there's no money, there's nothing they can do, and that means their money is gone, " one entrepreneur concluded.

So most of the time investors will be stuck with a six-month dead line and will compare the cost of resetting the business.

It's very important to keep the company alive, and layoffs are often a way to save yourself at a particular time, as long as the company has money on its books, there may be opportunities for the future, one Renminbi VC investor told CNNMONEY. "When the money is spent, it goes away, but when the staff is gone, they can hire again. "

The cost of wrongful lay-offs

The outbreak was a sudden factor, making it difficult for founders to make decisions, especially about layoffs, because of the unpredictable pace and duration of work.

The wrong way to lay off people is fatal. In the eyes of many of the founders interviewed by CNNMONEY, indecision and sloppiness can stall layoffs and affect the overall situation.

"When you find something is wrong, you can't hesitate. You should just snap everything down and start over. It depends on how well you see it,"says Chen Wu, a travel industry founder.

In 2016, Chen Wu was working as a bike entrepreneur. The company is underperforming, money is tight, investors are recommending layoffs, and the company needs to cut from 100 to 30 people. Unable to make up his mind, Chen Wu divided the cuts into three rounds, which could have been made in one go.

The result is a very big problem -- as if when you fire a bunch of people, the company becomes jittery and the rest of US panic. It's like I'm telling you to quit after a month. It's over. This person is positive, and within a month it's going to be negative for everyone else."

As layoffs dragged on, the company's atmosphere and business suffered, and some of the best people left. Later, Chen Wu resumed: "The most taboo thing about layoffs is that they are not thorough. Dragging your feet will only waste more bullets. Just like there are weeds in this lawn. Pull a little, grow a little, pull a little, grow a little. "

Sequoia capital, in a report, tells the story with a picture:

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Photo / Sequoia capital

During the 2008 financial crisis, the two companies, which were close in size, adopted very different strategies for job cuts. Company a was worried that the layoffs would raise outside questions and affect the company's hiring. At first, it cut market fees, then it increased its performance review to eliminate the bottom spot. Then, it couldn't stand up to the pressure from investors and began to make large-scale layoffs, eventually, the able-bodied run off, leaving behind people who are mostly passive grinders. Company B made it through the winter because the CEO cut the staff in one fell swoop, and although the losses were huge, the business was recovering.

Experienced ceos tend to take the easy way out, while younger ones are more likely to take the indirect route. Different choices lead to different results, but most ceos tend to make a company's choice.

Also in the 2008 financial crisis, once STAR START UP PPTV cash flow crisis, founder Yao Xin made the same mistakes as the CEO  , although the last PPTV barely passed, but also a big loss of vitality.

After the 2015 a-share crash and the 2016 venture capital bubble, Xu and Chen Wu made the same mistake. Eventually, Xu pulled out of the project to find another way out, and Chen Wu shut down the electric car project two years later.

This time around, many companies are in a similar position to 2008 and 2015, so how many of them will make the right choice CEO  ?

Whether it's Xin Yao, Chen Feng Xu, or Chen Wu, they're repeating the classic story of Sequoia Capital. While the backgrounds are different, the challenges for ceos are similar.

Someone has to be the bad guy, and in the case of layoffs, the CEO is the biggest bad guy. "sometimes there's really no way, the company ship is sinking, the life and death of all people, can only be objective to see, without mercy, " Chen Wu said.

There's also the question of WHO's going to make the cuts. Over the years, Chen Wu has come to the conclusion that the people who work for him are the ones who get to make the cuts.

Chen Wu, for example: If 10 people in project a need to be laid off for various reasons, the person in charge of project a should be allowed to lay off the 10 people and then cut himself. "really good leader, in accordance with the spirit of the profession should do so, otherwise the person in charge first withdrew, the burden to HR, the following people will have a lot of disputes with HR. "

Who Do we blame for the layoffs?

There are those who blame the CEO for ditching his or her peers, those who blame investors for their own well being, and those who blame the external environment for the force majeure.

"It's like a ship at sea, " one investor asked. "Now the ship is too heavy, and we have to throw some people off, or because the wind and waves are so strong that some people are tossed into the sea. Whose fault is it? "

Qiu Yiwu, founder of cloud creation, told finance and economics that the layoffs appear to be an issue of the external environment, but in essence they are due to internal management problems, "It is inevitable that the structure of a company is itself unreasonable during the period of expansion, " he said, arguing that particularly in the Internet industry, savage expansion must be followed by layoffs.

Linkedin's founder, Reid Hoffman, has written a book, lightning expansion, in which he talks about the different ways companies fight in four stages: PIRATES, marines, a unified continental army and police. Pirates and Marines belong to the early stages of corporate development, the rapid seizure of beaches to capture the continent, and the army and police to rule and maintain order.

In the early stage of beach, pay attention to the team's unconditional trust, the rapid expansion of the external, because only to take the territory, the enterprise may further in-depth development. "Many wind gap projects, in the stage of barbaric expansion, are actually fighting for beaches. Guns and artillery are indiscriminate, and it is normal to waste some bullets, " Qiu said.

When the beach-holding failed, in the process of troop withdrawal, layoffs occurred. In addition, once a major unexpected event, such as a snowstorm, a large area of the cold wave, epidemic, and so on, will lead to the beach operation of the sudden shock, forced into layoffs.

This year's outbreak has been a storm for many Internet companies, which are expanding rapidly, or for companies that are racing to secure land offline. Many of the Internet companies that raised a lot of money in 2019 and doubled their teams were laid off during the epidemic. In the case of last year's Tuyere e-cigarette industry, several e-cigarette company ceos told CNNMONEY that significant job cuts had already been made and that further job cuts would be considered.

"This is the same transmission effect as the financial crisis in 2008 and the capital cold winter in 2015, " Xu said.

But a successful beach grab does not mean a one-off. In the transition from the Marine Corps to the Military Police, the paradigm shift will bring about a change in organizational structure, "When the legitimate army is in charge, those who are undisciplined and inefficient will be driven out. "

"It is cruel to say, but this is the reality, " said Qiu. "That is to say, if I do not fight this battle, I will die. If I fight it, I may die. "

Chen Wu went through something that many people don't understand about the mass layoffs: "You know how stressful it is. I feel like I've done something wrong. I'm so depressed, I feel so guilty, I feel so guilty, I feel like it's my fault the company didn't do a good job and I'm going to have to lay off people. "

A restaurant owner told Caijing that when the outbreak lasted for a month, he also seriously considered laying off workers, but he did not talk to them in the end, "I don't know where to start, but in the end, I think I'll pass. Just hang in there, and maybe it'll pass. "

Companies, like people, will eat a lot of diarrhea, virus infection will get sick, and then will vomit diarrhea, the need to pass out the body of toxins.

But Qiu believes that most ceos still have the spirit of entrepreneurship, corporate social responsibility is also strengthening, "we are fighting the epidemic this war, I believe that enterprises are still willing to shoulder the burden. "

"when the next rainy season comes, the ground will be green grass and the flowers will be blooming all the time, " said Wang Zeqi, the founder of Platt.

* The caption is from visual China. At the request of the interviewee, Xu and Chen Wu were given pseudonyms. The in-depth report on the "Innovative Economic War Disease Plan" and the Salon documentary can be read on the public menu "war disease plan" .
